Legal_Issue: Whether the term 'medicine' includes mechanical devices used to administer active substances
Governing_Law: The Regulations defining 'medicine' as a substance intended or capable of being used for diagnosis, treatment, etc.
Procedural_Stage: Application for prohibition under the 30-month stay period
Legal_Rule: The term 'medicine' does not include mechanical devices such as inhalers, even if used to administer pharmaceutical substances
Procedural_Issue: Interpretation of regulatory definition and applicability to mechanical delivery devices
Grounds_for_Claim: Glaxo Group Limited claimed patent infringement by Novopharm regarding generic inhalers
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim rejected; inhalers not considered 'medicine' under the Regulations
Key_Evidence_Considered: Definition of 'medicine', previous case law on pharmaceutical compositions
Applicant_Challenge: Glaxo sought to prevent approval of generic inhalers based on patent rights
Court_Result: Dismissed application; 30-month period continues pending appeals
Defendant_Response: Novopharm argued that inhalers are devices, not medicines, and thus outside the scope of the patent protection under the Regulations
Remedy_Requested: Prevention of regulatory approval for generic inhalers
Remedy_Sought: Prohibition of approval for generic inhalers
Claimant_Status: Glaxo Group Limited as patent holder
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Inhalers do not qualify as 'medicine' under the Regulations
Governing_Rule: Definition of 'medicine' excludes non-ingestible mechanical devices
